So what kind of typefaces do they generally use for mobile phones for texting etc?

You’re definitely being too open. Each DVD player manufacturer will choose whatever typeface they want for their players. Generally it will be a Grotesk like Helvetica, though I’ve seen Arial and Futura used too.

As for mobile phone OS fonts - they will usually be proprietary to the phone company, e.g. Nokia Sans and its bitmap counterpart designed by Erik Spiekermann.

I was wondering why this particular forum of mine has a red asteric next to it? Have I done something wrong?

Well, actually, now that you mention it, I don’t even know why and I’m friggin’ head moderator of this forum! :^)

Please bear with me while I ask the powers that be.
The red asterisk means a thread which you, the reader, has not read or has new content.
Scratch that. The red asterisk signifies a new thread which you, the reader, hasn’t viewed yet.

That’s why I don’t see any asterisks anymore! I did a full check up to a couple of days back. :^D

Mystery solved.
haha :D

In the future you should indicate ( using your original post as a starting point ) if you mean the type used printed on the buttons, for the logo, or for the parts that light up - or whatever. Be as specific & thoughtful as possible. AND it would be a good idea to post an image if you want a type to be identified.

When I first read the title of your question I was keen to read the rest & to help but after I read how unspecfic the question was I thought to myself. ’Why can’t she be asked to think this question through a bit better?’ And then I thought ’If she can’t be asked - then neither can I’.

If you ask lazy unspecific questions in future I wil ignore them. If you ask careful specific questions I will try to help.

Eben,  
When you write:  
<cite>“Why can’t she be asked to think this question through a bit better?”</cite>  
I think you mean:  
“Why can’t she be ARSED to think this question through a bit better?”

I have heard a few non-English people mistake the UK term “arsed” for the southern English pronunciation of “asked”. It was first brought to my attention when I lived with a Greek man who tried to pick up local expressions.

So, If she can’t be ARSED - then neither can you, right?

Arsed is from arse (ass, bottom, buttocks, posterior - whatever)

“I can’t be arsed” doesn’t actually make much sense but that’s the correct term. It means “I can’t be bothered”, I once heard that it comes from “I can’t be bothered to get up off my arse to ... [whatever]” but I don’t really know and I can’t be arsed to Google it.

“Arse” gets through the profanity filter but the US version does not ... interesting.

All the UK and Irish people can talk mild filth without censorship.

<cite> All the UK and Irish people can talk mild filth without censorship. </cite>
